fields.value: Senate Unpassed Legislation 1911, H 1038 joint committee on the judiciary - leave to withdraw, SC1/series 231, Petition of Frederick W. Peabody

authorName.value: Digital Archive of Massachusetts Anti-Slavery and Anti-Segregation Petitions, Massachusetts Archives, Boston MA

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Petition subject: Marriage laws

Original: http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:FHCL:25763671

Date of creation: (unknown)

Petition location: Boston

Legislator, committee, or address that the petition was sent to: Courtenay Crocker, Boston; committee on the judiciary

Selected signatures:

  1. Frederick W. Peabody

Actions taken on dates: 1911-01-18,1911-01-24

Legislative action: Received in the House on January 18, 1911 and referred to the committee on the judiciary and sent for concurrence and received in the Senate on January 24, 1911 and concurred

Total signatures: 1

Legislative action summary: Received, referred, sent, received, concurred

Legal voter signatures (males not identified as non-legal): 1

Female only signatures: No

Identifications of signatories: citizens

Prayer format was printed vs. manuscript: Printed

Additional non-petition or unrelated documents available at archive: additional documents available

Additional archivist notes: Interracial marriage, miscegenation, Caucasian race, racial purity, 1843, slavery, militant abolitionists, includes address, ["â€¦That in all other sections of the world where there ever has been such admixture of Caucasian and Negro blood, it has heretofore been represented in the progeny of males of the Caucasian race and females of the Negro race; but that in this Commonwealth the Caucasian race is being degraded and tainted through the descendants of men of the negro race and women of the Caucasian race. That for every mulatto child born of a white mother the proper descendant of that mother, to wit, a white child, is displaced, and an injury in a double sense inflicted upon the white race..."], ["...That since that time this Commonwealth has held out to the Negro race in the Southern part of the country the inducement of marriage here with a white person, until now there can be no doubt that the lure of the male negro to Massachusetts is the hope and expectation of a white wife..."], [bill stated: "Section 1. No White person shall intermarry with a Negro, Indian, or Mulatto."]

Location of the petition at the Massachusetts Archives of the Commonwealth: Senate Unpassed 1911, H 1038 joint committee on the judiciary - leave to withdraw
